instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message:
got this laptop in from a customer. Small signs of liquid damage near usb ports, especially on <CAPACITOR>C2975</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C2978</CAPACITOR>. I don't usually work on the newer models so just wanted some advice before I dive in.
I get 20V on both usb ports but 0.01-0.03A so not turning on
I cleaned the corrosion with alcohol and toothbrush, but I'm measuring a short across <CAPACITOR>C2975</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C2978</CAPACITOR>, so basically between <SIGNAL>PP3V3_TBT_X_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP0V9_X_SVR_AGND</SIGNAL>. I think I can see a heartbeat if I use alcohol on <CAPACITOR>C2975</CAPACITOR>, but I'm afraid to remove it because of <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> on the other side of the board. Is it safe to use hot air to remove it or should I wedge it off with my soldering iron.
Also, I'm worried the short might actually be on <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, any advice for removing the shield so I can check?

Thanks a lot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message:
Using JBC NASE station makes your life easy.
You can easy remove small components (0201, 0402), close to sensitive chips.

[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.google.com/search?q=jbc+nase+station&client=firefox-b-d&hl=es&sxsrf=ALeKk00JGifoG2VcezLPxyXm0GLQik21Ng:1599251698868&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjIlavrrNDrAhVhDmMBHWC3BY4Q_AUoAXoECAsQAw&biw=1680&bih=866[/URL]

If you remove <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>, charger ports must still work.
You should test if macOS can recognize other USB devices; maybe only USB 2.0, like pendrive, mouse...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message:
JBC are very nice, but I can't afford right now. I managed to replace <CAPACITOR>C2975</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C2978</CAPACITOR> with soldering iron and assistive hot air, now short is gone and machine powers on.

Only issue left seems to be slight stagelight effect at bottom of screen. Could this be cause by liquid damage or is it the backlight flex cable issue? Customer doesn't know if it was there before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message:
Flex causes backlight flickering, or image/backlight come and go when you move the lid.
Display should be affected by liquid this time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message: the effect is very faint, and consistent at all display angles. I've cleaned the small (i mean tiny) bits of corrosion on the display board and backlight connectors, but it made no change. Looks clean under the shields but I haven't removed them. Anything else I can do without changing screen or just tell the customer to live with it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message:
I can only think about liquid inside display assembly.
Light diffusion has been affected,..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0.03A
threads.message: ok, thank you. I will call this done and see what customer thinks, but I don't think it's that bad. Maybe they can get a new display from apple when the backlight flex fails haha
